item.title: Slovak Lawmakers Approve Resolution to Oppose Russia Sanctions
item.description: Slovak lawmakers approved a resolution that empowers government members to not support new sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: Robert Fico

item.title: Germany to Do NATO ‘Heavy Lifting’ as Allies Ratchet Up Spending
item.description: Germany’s defense chief said his country will need to boost its armed forces by as many as 60,000 active soldiers as NATO member states commit to ramping up defense spending to deter Russia’s military threat.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Boris Pistorius, Germany’s defense minister, center, and Pete Hegseth, US secretary of defense, right, at NATO meeting on June 5.

item.title: The World’s Strongmen are Confounding Dealmaker Trump
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump speaks from the Truman balcony during a Summer soiree on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, DC, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: Bill Ackman Is Tweeting His Way Through It
item.description: The Wall Street billionaire remade himself into a very-online, Trump-loving culture warrior. Now he wants to be the next Warren Buffett.
item.dc:creator: Annie Massa, Katherine Burton

item.title: Israel’s Government Wobbles as Netanyahu Allies Threaten Exit
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s ruling coalition faces the possibility of collapse and early elections after his ultra-Orthodox partners threatened to bring down the government.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein, Marissa Newman

media:content.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu

item.title: Burundi Holds Legislative Vote, Excludes Main Opposition Leader
item.description: Burundi is holding elections for the National Assembly and local councils that have excluded the main opposition in one of the world’s poorest nations.
item.dc:creator: Desire Nimubona

media:content.media:description: Voters queue as they wait to cast their ballots for the Burundi legislative elections at Musama Primary School in Gitega on June 5.

item.title: US Is Reworking Subsidy Awards to Chipmakers, Lutnick Says
item.description: US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the Trump administration has been reworking agreements forged with semiconductor makers under the 2022 Chips Act to secure what he called better terms aimed at generating additional domestic investment.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: A bare wafer stacker sorts silicon wafers in Building 51 at Micron Technology Inc. headquarters in Boise, Idaho, US, on Monday, June 10, 2024. The US announced in April its plans to award Micron Technology Inc. $6.1 billion in grants and as much as $7.5 billion in loans to help the memory-chip maker build new American factories, rounding out a slew of major federal awards for advanced semiconductor manufacturing. Photographer: Kyle Green/Bloomberg

item.title: US Plans Wider China Tech Curbs Targeting Subsidiaries
item.description: The Trump administration plans to broaden restrictions on China’s tech sector with new regulations to capture subsidiaries of companies under US curbs.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: A wafer on display at the Semicon China expo in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The expo runs through March 22.

item.title: Turkey Dismisses Opposition Mayors in Widening Graft Probe
item.description: Turkish authorities removed five local opposition mayors from office and launched an investigation into their party leader in a widening judicial crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Taylan Bilgic

media:content.media:description: People wave flags and chant slogans during a mass protest rally in support of the arrested Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu in Izmir, Turkey, on May 19.

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s New Travel Ban
item.description: US President Donald Trump signed a proclamation on June 4 to block citizens of 12 countries, mostly in the Middle East and Africa, from entering the US.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: People wait outside an immigration court in New York, on June 3. Photographer: Spencer Platt/Getty Images North America

item.title: Israel-Backed Gaza Aid Group Suspends Operations for Second Day
item.description: An Israel- and US-backed mechanism to distribute food in Gaza suspended operations for a second day following a series of deadly incidents near its sites that drew international criticism.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: People line up at a meal distribution point in Nuseirat, central Gaza, on June 4, 2025. Photographer: Eyad Baba/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump’s Administration Has Asked Ally Serbia to Accept Deportees
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration is pushing Serbia and other Balkan nations to take in migrants deported from the US, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Annie Massa, Jenny Leonard, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: EU Gets Court Boost in Right to Retaliate Against Trump Tariffs
item.description: The European Union’s power to impose retaliatory tariffs on US goods and services won a legal boost from an adviser to the bloc’s top court, as the 27-member jurisdiction continues to spar with President Donald Trump over trade.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Stolton

media:content.media:description: Zippo lighters at the company's plant in Bradford, Pennsylvania, US.

item.title: David Jolly, Trump critic and Former GOP Congressman, to Run For Florida Governor as Democrat
item.description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) — A former Republican congressman and vocal critic of Donald Trump says he wants to become governor in the president’s adopted home state of Florida, and that he’s running as a Democrat.

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JUNE 04: David Jolly speaks at The Common Good Town Hall "Bridging America's Divide" at New-York Historical Society on June 04, 2024 in New York City. (Photo by Sylvain Gaboury/Patrick McMullan via Getty Images)

item.title: OECD Backs SARB Push to Lower South Africa’s Inflation Target
item.description: Lowering South Africa’s inflation target would drive economic growth and international competitiveness, said the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, echoing the country’s central bank.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana.

item.title: Jersey City’s Mayor on How the City Built So Much Housing
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

item.title: Indonesia Mulls China’s Offer of Battle-Tested J-10 Fighter Jets
item.description: Indonesia said China has offered to sell it J-10 jets, the fighter aircraft that were recently battle-tested in Pakistan’s clashes with India over Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: People's Liberation Army Air Force (PLAAF) Chengdu J-10 fighter jets, manufactured by Chengdu Aerospace Corp., a unit of Aviation Industry Corp. of China (AVIC), fly during an aerobatics display during the China International Aviation & Aerospace Exhibition in Zhuhai, Guangdong province, China, on Saturday, Nov. 15, 2014. The air show takes place from Nov. 11-16.

item.title: Vietnam Sends Trade Demand Reply as US Turns Up China Heat
item.description: Vietnam said it is responding to US demands with “goodwill” and has sent a written reply to US trade requests after the Trump administration vowed to keep pressuring the Southeast Asian nation to reduce its role in China supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen, Francesca Stevens

item.title: China Offers $1,400 Bounty for Arrests of Taiwan Cyberwarriors
item.description: China placed a bounty on cyberwarriors working for Taiwan’s Defense Ministry, extending its campaign to squeeze President Lai Ching-te.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Wang

media:content.media:description: Computer code and text displayed on computer screens. Photographer: Bloomberg Creative Photos/Bloomberg Creative Collection

item.title: Ex-Australia PM Says He Could Have Halted Port Lease to Chinese Firm
item.description: Former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said he could have halted the lease of the Port of Darwin to a Chinese company shortly after coming to power a decade ago — pulling the plug on a deal the US “never liked.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Malcolm Turnbull Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: Germany’s Got a Problem, and It’s More Than Donald Trump
item.description: As Donald Trump pushes ahead with his campaign to transform the way the world does business, Germany is uniquely vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Marilen Martin

media:content.media:description: A viewing point looking out over the Schwelgern coking plant at ThyssenKrupp’s Duisburg steelworks in April.

item.title: Elon Musk Urges Americans Take Action to ‘Kill’ Trump Tax Cut Bill
item.description: Elon Musk is on a mission to block President Donald Trump’s tax bill after he tried — and failed — to convince Republican lawmakers to preserve valuable tax credits for electric vehicles in the legislation, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office on Friday, May 30.

item.title: Xi Tells Lukashenko China Will Hold Military Parade on Sept. 3
item.description: President Xi Jinping said China will hold a military parade to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II on Sept. 3, an event that’s expected to bring his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Jing Li, Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Photo by Kevin Frayer/Getty Images Photographer: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images AsiaPac

item.title: Trump Orders Inquiry Into Biden’s Health, Use of Autopen
item.description: President Donald Trump directed aides to investigate whether former President Joe Biden’s staff conspired to hide information about his health from the public and enacted any executive actions without his predecessor’s knowledge.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Joe Biden Photographer: Chris Kleponis/CNP

item.title: Trump Stymied in ‘Art of the Deal’ Approach to World’s Strongmen
item.description: President Donald Trump has long boasted about his ability to cut deals with the world’s strongmen. But now that he’s back in the White House, his charms haven’t worked on the leaders he professes to admire.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Courtney McBride

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Bars Foreign Students From Entering US to Attend Harvard
item.description: President Donald Trump signed an executive action that prevents foreign nationals from entering the US to study at Harvard University, accusing the school of failing to implement discipline on campus and fostering a dramatic rise in crime.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Trump has sought to reshape Harvard’s policies on a wide-range of issues, including admissions and faculty hiring practices.

item.title: Kim Vows Full Backing for Putin as Ties With Russia Deepen
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un reiterated his pledge to unconditionally support Russian President Vladimir Putin, state media said, as the sanctions-defying alliance between the two countries raises security concerns in the region.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: In this photo provided by the North Korean government, Kim Jong Un, second right, meets with Sergei Shoigu, left, in Pyongyang, North Korea, on June 4. Source: Korean Central News Agency/Korea News Service/AP Photo

item.title: US to Keep Pressure on Vietnam Over China Imports, Lutnick Says
item.description: The Trump administration will keep up pressure on Vietnam as long as it keeps re-exporting a significant amount of Chinese products to the US, according to Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes operate at the Tan Vu Terminal, operated by Vietnam Maritime Corp., at Haiphong Port in Haiphong, Vietnam, on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025. Vietnam Maritime, the state-owned shipping, logistics and seaports company previously known as Vietnam National Shipping Lines or Vinalines, plans to expand its fleet by 20% annually in the next five years,

item.title: The Rare-Earth Fight Imperiling US-China Trade Peace, Explained
item.description: Markets cheered in early May when the US and China agreed in Geneva to lower tariffs and other barriers. But after a few weeks, the shine started to come off that deal, with China accusing the US of violating it with new restrictions and the US saying China failed to honor promises on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Neodymium is displayed at the Inner Mongolia Baotou Steel Rare-Earth Hi-Tech Co. factory in Baotou, Inner Mongolia, China, on Wednesday, May 5, 2010. A generation after Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping made mastering neodymium and 16 other elements known as rare-earths a priority, China has cornered the market, with far-reaching effects ranging from job losses and global trade to U.S. national security.

item.title: Hong Kong Bolsters Top Court With First Foreign Judge in a Year
item.description: Hong Kong has appointed a retired New Zealand judge to its top court, the first foreign justice named to the appellate body in over a year following record resignations that threatened to undermine confidence in the judicial system.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong

media:content.media:description: The Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong.
